author: sky.cactus
content: My biggest fear with trusted setups is that the cryptography is complicated and there are like 5 people in the world whowgrok it enough to actually validate the source code, and if we are lucky two of them will actually look at the source code, and the chances that they find/recognize bugs is low.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is my problem with Tornado.cash's trusted setup for example, I'm not confident that more than one person has actually validated the code for it.

author: sky.cactus
content: And by validated I mean actually sat down and audited it themselves, looking for exploits in the cryptography or neighboring concepts.

author: sky.cactus
content: I looked at the code and have no idea if it is correct or not, for example.

author: sky.cactus
content: And when I asked other auditors if it was sound they basically said "it looks right I guess?"

author: paulhauner
content: Isn't this a common issue among *all* trusted cryptography that we mitigate via paying for reviews from professionals?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, but at least with ECDSA it is well established with a long history and a lot of review.

author: sky.cactus
content: Same with hashing algorithms.  I feel like both are used *way* more broadly by humanity and you can easily find a library to compare results against, and the library doesn't have to be tightly integrated with the project and have custom code around it.

author: sky.cactus
content: In most of cryptography there is just a single pure function, and you can find dozens of battle tested implementations to compare results against.  With zkProofs and trusted setups, the cryptography has to be woven much more tightly into your code.  Plus the set of cryptographers who understand it is smaller as well.  I have implemented my own keccak256 and secp256k1 libraries, but I have no clue how zkProofs and trusted setup works (as an anecdotal example).

author: paulhauner
content: Sure, the crypto is complex. But we can actually ensure people look at the code (by paying them) and we certainly shouldn't settle for any review that equates to "looks right i guess". If you're only willing to trust crypto with ECDSA history then I think you're going to feel uncomfortable with BLS too. We need to push boundaries with crypto at *some point*, so I think we should be careful with impeding innovation by just declaring it impossible to be analyzed just because *some* projects have failed to get a proper analysis.

author: sky.cactus
content: I can appreciate that argument.  Basically my argument boils down to, "how much does a trusted setup help us with design, and is that worth the risks it introduces of using novel cryptography?"

author: sky.cactus
content: If it is just, "we can save a couple bytes on the wire" then it isn't worth it.  If it is, "we have no other solution to a hard problem that we must solve" then I'm ok with it.
